A Matter of Time?

July 31st, 2005 · No Comments

England has a substantial Muslim community including several “rabid” clerics. So the London tube bombings, while horrible, were not any particular surprise especially given England’s support with the US in Iraq. My question: is France or the Netherlands next? Both also have large Muslim communities with alarming trends in radicalism popping up [...]

Bad Writing

July 30th, 2005 · No Comments

The competition highlights literary achievements of the most dubious sort — terrifyingly bad sentences that take their inspiration from minor writer Edward George Earl Bulwer-Lytton, whose 1830 novel “Paul Clifford” began, “It was a dark and stormy night.”

There’s some hilarious lines in here. I especially liked the winner of the Western category.

My Latest Foray into Open Source

July 28th, 2005 · 1 Comment

Presenting Light Fixture.

Light Fixture is a Java component which helps you model test scenario data using a simple text descriptor. You describe your beans and Light Fixture will instantiate the beans and optionally persist them to a database at the same time. In essence it allows you to create lightweight test fixtures.

This was something I [...]

Make Millions!

July 24th, 2005 · 4 Comments

Why can’t someone develop grass that grows 2″ tall and then stops? My grass just keeps growing and growing and GROWING. Having to mow every 1-2 weeks during the hot Texas summer is miserable. Nature is a lot like Rath’s software: great in theory but bad in implementation.

Acegi Patch

July 23rd, 2005 · No Comments

After testing out Acegi Security the other night, I found a small scalability problem with their anonymous credentials support: accessing a public resource anonymously caused an HttpSession to be created. I submitted a patch to fix the behavior and it was accepted for their upcoming 0.9.0 release:
AnonymousProcessingFilter now has a removeAfterRequest property, which defaults [...]
